petitioner.name: HEMI GROUP, LLC AND KAI GACHUPIN

respondent.name:
No. 08-969
CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument this afternoon in Case 08-969, Hemi Group v. The City of New York. Mr. Barnhouse.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why -- why isn't the money property?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, isn't a lawsuit with a potential recovery regarded as property of an individual?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There is no such adjective -- I know we have used it, but there is no such adjective as "choate." There is "inchoate," but the opposite of "inchoate" is not "choate."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Any more than the -- I don't know. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Exactly. Yes. It's like "gruntled."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Exactly. "Disgruntled" and the opposite of "disgruntled" is "gruntled."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought the status of taxes owing for wire fraud purposes was settled in Pasquantino. There it was a question of alcohol taxes owed to Canada. There were taxes due, but not paid. So why doesn't Pasquantino settle at least the property question that taxes owed to a sovereign qualify as property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, there are certainly differences from this case, and it wasn't a RICO case, either. But why would the determination of what - - whether an amount owed to a government qualifies as property, why wouldn't -- why would that answer differ?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There was no assessment by Canada in the Pasquantino case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: They said the -- the defendant was smuggling liquor into Canada and getting it there without paying the Canadians' exorbitant taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But we're talking about -- only about property, not standing or anything else. And in Pasquantino, the Court said that a scheme aimed -- aimed at depriving Canada of money to which it was entitled by law qualifies as property for wire fraud purposes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So why is this different? I mean, it's clear that "property" can mean that. You acknowledge that it can mean the government's entitlement to money from taxes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So it can mean that. Now why -- why should we say it doesn't mean that here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is the word "property" used in the antitrust laws?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What does it say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it -- and it's clear that for purposes of the antitrust laws, property does not include the government's entitlement to income from taxes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The Hawaii case didn't involve a claim to taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Right, and parens patriae for the community at large.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But none of them involved a claim to taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, but that -- that's something different. This isn't just the general, you know, you hurt the economy and therefore you hurt the State. Here, what they're saying is: You caused people who owed me taxes not to pay taxes, an identified sum of money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it might have been inchoate but still -- they would have to be prove that, I assume, in the litigation here, wouldn't they? I mean, let's assume we let the litigation go forward. Wouldn't they have to prove what taxes were not paid?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So worry about that later. I mean, just because some of them might be difficult to prove or not provable doesn't mean that the rest that are very clear do not constitute property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's a different issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're going to talk about that one, aren't you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You've got it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Putting aside the fact that the Jenkins Act information would be sent to the State rather than the city, why -- how can you -- how can it be said that at this stage of the litigation that it's farfetched that having a statement on the website "No taxes due" is -- doesn't cause people to purchase those cigarettes for the very purpose of avoiding the taxes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What is it, a user tax once it gets into the city?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Like automobiles.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Just like automobiles. If you buy a car out of the State, you haven't paid the State sales tax, but if you bring it into the State, you have to pay a use tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's all it was alleged that these websites said, "tax-free"? They said "tax-free"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: "Sales are tax-free." That's very clever.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No -- "no tobacco tax"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But there is a tobacco tax, isn't there? Don't you -- wouldn't you call that use tax a tax on tobacco?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why isn't that just a question -- a substantive fraud question, rather than a proximate cause question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Is it -- is it fraudulent to say "sales are tax-free" as opposed to, you know, saying no taxes are due?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It was injured because it couldn't find its citizens because it didn't know who they were. And that was the whole idea of the Jenkins Act, was to help States find the people who were evading the payment of the use tax on the cigarettes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, suppose -- suppose you had a case in which an individual that lives in New York goes to a person with a supply of cigarettes outside the State and says: I want to buy a lot of cigarettes and I don't want to pay taxes; can you help me? And they agree on an arrangement to ship, to ship the cigarettes. Is there proximate cause? Is it there if the city sues for injury in that hypothetical case? Would you say there's no proximate cause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And you think the city - - and you think the city cannot show proximate cause in a suit for its injury against the seller of the cigarettes? You think there's no proximate cause in that hypothetical case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Even though those are the only two people that have made the arrangement, and that was the whole purpose and intent of the arrangement? And you still say there's no proximate cause?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Does your answer to Justice Kennedy depend upon a notion that the causation standard as -- in RICO is different than general proximate cause standards in tort law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can you go back to the question I had asked you and was not finished getting your position on. Jenkins requires report to the State. You say the city was not within the zone of interest. But from the point of view of the sellers, the out-of-state sellers of cigarettes, my goodness, would they really want not only to have the burden of sending a list of names to the State, but to every county and municipality? Isn't it the -- just as it is in New York, there is a working relationship. The State gets all the names, and then it sends the names to the cities. You -- you -- I -- you're suggesting that it would be okay if the Jenkins Act had made it even more burdensome to the cigarette sellers by saying not only do you have to disclose to the State but also to any municipality that independently taxes cigarettes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is it -- we're told that New York City and New York State have a tax information - sharing agreement pursuant to which the State does share this information with the city.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, what do you do with -- what do you do with Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical? I mean, she can pursue her own question, but I'm interested in the answer. Her question is, suppose the statute were amended so that the information had to be given to the city as well as to the State; would the case then be different, hypothetical case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Are there any sanctions for failing to comply with the Jenkins Act, just on its own, without having to go through RICO?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But you don't -- you don't think that proximate cause is satisfied only with respect to the person who is supposed to be paying the taxes? If there's some way in which someone else contributes or makes it feasible or makes it more likely that the person is not going to pay his taxes, that's not automatically outside the scope of proximate cause, is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How many people who buy cigarettes out of State come back to their home State and voluntarily pay the use tax?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't there some exemption, anyway, for a couple of cartons?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: For what, two cartons?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it needs the names so it can collect anything. Otherwise, how is it -- how - - how would it ever know?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And they don't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It would probably cost them more to collect than -- than it's worth the money, don't you think, to sue individual citizens after they get the names?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we know if these Jenkins Act lists -- are they in fact maintained by the State?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Koerner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. Did -- was there some statute at issue in that case which required not just an interest, but an interest in property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry, because of -- because of what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Before you get to Anza, this might be a good time to ask because I don't think we focused on this in Pasquantino. But if in fact the failure of a State to collect a tax is property, then why isn't every corporation that files an income tax return and makes two false statements automatically liable for RICO? I mean - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that would mean the States have a new method, which I don't think they use, a new method of collecting treble taxes from anyone who makes two false statements or a false statement in two income tax returns, and it would seem to me that would have vast repercussions. I mean, it might be very beneficial; the States are having a deficit crisis; but - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: How, how -- why would it not be - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But they left -- they don't have the RICO predicate, not paying your State taxes. But in effect you would read into the RICO predicate protecting States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That may be, but nobody focused on this issue. So -- so that's what's bothering me. What is the -- what is the stopping place?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or is there one? And if there is none, how do we reconcile this view of - - they're suggesting a stopping place, Anza and Pasquantino to the contrary. Right. But they're suggesting a stopping place on a matter that hasn't come up.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or focused on. It's come up but not focused on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So in your view California - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- which has a $10 billion deficit, could go through, find every instance where a corporation made two false statements in two tax returns, one in each, and collect treble what they're owed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It doesn't say systematic understatement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It says two - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- predicate acts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the predicate acts are a deliberate false statement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If they did, then why didn't they put in not paying your State tax returns as a predicate act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh, well, that cuts against you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because if they put in one, your theory -- they don't even need, whether they need that or not. Your theory applies to every tax, every tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, but go back to my question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My question is, forget the cigarette taxes. If I accept your argument, am I then saying that California, New York, and every other State that's owed money by corporations in their taxes can go through, look for two tax returns that have a false statement in them that were mailed in, and thereby collect RICO damages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that's a pretty far-reaching - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do you know anybody, any court that has ever said that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why would - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why should that help?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If Congress wanted that result, why didn't they put in as a predicate act not paying your income tax or not paying your State tax?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, but Congress said - - we were just told by counsel for the Petitioner, Congress said you can only -- only the Federal prosecutor can sue for violations of Jenkins - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- not New York City, not New York State - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- and it's a misdemeanor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And now you -- you are saying the Jenkins Act gives you a basis to go after what are basically aiders and abettors of use tax violations?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But do you know -- do we know that? Do we know whether the Petitioner has in fact filed the Jenkins Act report with New York State?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. So I think that their response to the mail and fraud is, you're right, it is all mail -- it is all mail fraud. All these tax violations, in fact every one, you mail in your tax return normally.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So all of these would be mail fraud. But mail fraud is not a treble damages statute. And therefore the question is who will prosecute, State or Federal? So normally it's State if it's a State tax. But it's one thing to say Congress didn't care about that and quite another thing to say that Congress didn't care if the States were going to use this in order to collect three times what the taxes are owed. And so they're looking for a way to cut off this tax liability for ordinary, simpleminded tax - - failure to pay your State taxes. And that's why they've hit on this idea of the antitrust. I don't know if that's a satisfactory idea. I don't see the solution. I think I see the problem.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But it was injured by the consumer's failure -- it was injured by the consumer's failure to pay the taxes. That is an intervening cause.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Now, why shouldn't that be the end of the causation chain?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You're suing him for setting up the ambiance?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: In order to -- in order to -- to prevail on that theory, would you have to prove that these -- these alleged misrepresentations in fact caused people not to pay taxes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You would have -- you would have to prove that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And you think you could prove that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What -- what percentage of the -- of the residents of New York State or New York City voluntarily pay a use tax on their income tax returns for items that they purchase on the Internet?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Would you make a guess?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So how can you call it -- I mean, part of the problem with calling it property is there -- there is such a low chance of recovery of the amount owed here. Even if the Jenkins Act filing had been made, you still have to -- have to assume that this - - number one, you have to assume that the State would turn the list over to the city, which the State isn't required to do.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that may be, but the State isn't required to, and the State can terminate that agreement whenever it likes. But, secondly, after you get the information we have to assume that you're going to move against these people.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Does it -- does it affect your ambiance theory that the website has the language that your friend told us is on it, that you have to -- you know, this is -- viability varies from State to State or whatever the exact language is?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That still creates the ambiance?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could you satisfy Justice Breyer's concern -- and maybe the answer is not -- by saying that if there were a corporation that went around to California taxpayers and said, we have a way to avoid taxes, that then there would be a RICO violation, and that would be closer to your case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well -- well, you're certainly consistent and persistent on that point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it -- it would seem to me -- it would seem to me that I gave you a way to differentiate this case. And isn't that consistent with RICO because we have a very specific enterprise here?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but the definition and giving scope and meaning to the concept of proximate cause is one that's in our bailiwick.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we know -- you gave an instance in your brief or two instances of successful attempts to recoup from the taxpayer, that is the cigarette buyer. Did those come about because the city received the Jenkins Act list from the State? How did the city get - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, you follow up by writing them a letter and what your footnote 8 says is, when you wrote them a letter, about half of them coughed -- coughed up the tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They may have been the foolish half. Did - - (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Were the other -- were the other half pursued by the city?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not yet. I don't - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It can't be worth it. It can't possibly be worth it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why is what they're doing any different from what out-of-State mail order houses have done in -- they set -- they set up in States without a sales tax, they ship into a State that has a compensating use tax, that, apart from automobiles, I don't know is ever collected.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but that's because in every one of those cases, or at least in many of them, we kind of wring our hands and say, well, we don't have any choice, this is what Congress did, and we're faithful to that intent. But I guess, as I tried to point out earlier, this is a different question. This is the usual judicial application of concepts of proximate cause, and I would have thought concern about how broad RICO was written and how broadly it has been interpreted would cause us to look very carefully to the proximate cause question.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No -- I don't understand that. The injury is directly caused by the consumers who don't pay the taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So do you say then that proximate cause is in part established because of the specific intent? Is that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I'm glad -- I'm glad you said that, because the Associated Contractors said specific intent is not - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But in -- in the world and in the lexicon of proximate cause, why is there proximate cause because this was the business model? How do I explain that in terms of proximate cause? There's not specific intent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I know. But there is no other -- take a case which was put to you as the seller who has many reasons for selling from out of State. They have a good catalog business, it's a well-established name, and so it's not just to avoid taxes. How is that different from what happened here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Okay, and in terms of proximate -- the universe of the law that we call proximate cause, how do you explain that? It's not specific intent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Reason on whose part? Some reason on whose part? On the seller's part or on the New York buyers' part? They will be -- the New York buyer is doing it because it's cheaper because he is not going to pay taxes on it. But it seems to me the seller couldn't care less whether the buyer pays taxes on it or not. So long as he pays the money for the cigarettes, the seller has gotten what the seller wanted.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So it's a mail order house and they put a little line on it, says: By the way, if you live out of State, no taxes, no sales taxes. Then they're also subject to RICO prosecution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, maybe that isn't completely true. Maybe it's a matter of convenience, at least theoretically. You buy stuff over the Internet, you buy these advertised cigarettes, the price seems all right, and you don't -- whether you pay the tax or not is your decision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, we were - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: To whom was the permanent misrepresentation made?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Usually you're not liable for misrepresentation unless it causes -- it's relied on. You really think that the -- that a large percentage of the people who were getting this stuff really, really were gulled into believing that New York State was somehow being done out of taxes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Really?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, I am sure the purchaser knows: I'm not going to pay taxes, even though I should pay taxes. But you're -- you're telling me that the only reason the purchaser doesn't pay taxes is because of this misrepresentation that you don't have to purchase -- you don't have to pay taxes. I've known a lot of New Yorkers, and not many of them are that gullible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But what if the seller didn't make those misstatements but just says -- the whole operation is set up exactly as this one is, but they don't have that statement in there; they just say: Get advice from your lawyer about whether you need to pay taxes or not. And what if that was the -- that was exactly the -- and then they all got the advice, and the lawyer says: They'll never catch you if you don't pay it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't want silence to be interpreted as acquiescence, but - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Just to get back at maybe the same point Justice Kennedy was raising, which is you're focusing on -- you keep saying: The whole purpose of this, look at their website. But the issue is proximate cause, and if you've got to go through the individual consumer, it's either proximate cause or not. And if the -- if the indirect nature of what they're doing because the direct cause is the consumer's failure to pay, it doesn't seem to me that their intent is pertinent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I'm -- I'm not sure. Let's talk about the contraband cigarette trafficking. I'm not sure that these people would be in violation of it. It makes it unlawful for any person knowingly to ship or transport, also receive, possess, sell, distribute, or purchase, cigarettes which bear no evidence of payment of applicable State or local cigarette taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But there is no applicable State or local cigarette tax upon the shipment of these cigarettes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's not what it says. It makes it unlawful to knowingly ship it when they bear no evidence of payment of applicable taxes, and - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- there is no applicable taxes at the time that they ship it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, I don't look at legislative history. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, why is it that you haven't argued -- why haven't you - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I don't see a difference - - would appreciate if you would tell me the difference between your argument as to this situation and the typical Internet site where I think a lot of people buy goods on the Internet, because they're convenient and also because they know that they're not going to have to pay State sales tax when they make those purchases.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why is that relevant as far as cause is concerned?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You have a company that is selling televisions, cameras, whatever over the Internet and they -- you know, you put your -- you put in your credit card information or whatever, and then it tells you, "sales tax due," and if they have no outlet in the State, it says "sales taxes due: Zero." What is the difference between that situation and this situation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Judge Winter in the Second Circuit said the State appears uninterested in enforcing the Jenkins Act and may not collate or maintain accurate records of reports from out-of-State vendors. What -- what was the basis for his statement that the State appears uninterested?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Barnhouse, you have four minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: On cause, why isn't it a causal connection for them to say, look, your clients don't tell them who's bought it. They're supposed to, but they don't. And if we got the information, we go write a letter to the people, and half of them would pay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But why isn't that a direct applicant action, but for foreseeable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yeah. I know, but there is more here. It is also foreseeable proximate cause. I mean, it is absolutely foreseeable, not just but for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Forget the website. What if there had been no website?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is it foreseeable that, when they don't know who owes the money, that the people won't pay, but when they know who owes the money, they can write them a letter, and half pay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Some pay. Some don't. They have the numbers there. They get more than half.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you get half-treble damages. What is that? One-and-a-half damages.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And, if you put people in front of railroad trains and half survive, then it's speculative?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, if you put somebody in front of a railroad train and half survive because they jumped, does that make it a speculative cause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And you say it's foreseeable that they won't get a lot of money. And that's what they're arguing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, what's the answer to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The reason is because of what your clients did, so it's but for and foreseeable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: End of case. Now, we go to the damage section.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But for -- no, no, your response is, but for, plus foreseeable, is not a definition of proximate cause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You need more than that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I took torts a long time ago. I thought that was part of it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no. There can be other things that cut it off. Proximate cause. Foreseeable. No kind of an event that would cut the causal chain, like some odd fluke or something.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No policy reason or others for cutting the chain. I mean, it's Torts 1 in 1962, okay?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Isn't it -- well, I don't know, maybe it's more -- but isn't it a proposition that you don't rely on illegal conduct, that the -- the assumption of illegal conduct cuts the chain? In other words, there's only proximate cause if you assume people are going to not pay taxes that they're due, contrary to law, and that that breaks the proximate cause chain?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, that you have to -- in order to maintain -- this is a helpful question. In order - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: In order to maintain the chain of connection, I thought you cannot rely, for one of those links in the chain, that a party is going to commit illegal action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that's wrong. I mean, at least for civil torts, you can -- there are a lot of cases where the landlord leaves out the bulb in the -- in the stairway and one of the residents gets mugged and he sues the landlord and wins, even though there is an intervening criminal act. Now, maybe what you want to argue is that that -- that has never been applied, to my knowledge, to either criminal liability or -- or penal provisions, and that maybe the -- an intervening criminal act does cut off causality, for purposes of penal statute, such as - - such as RICO. That would be a reasonable argument.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And a good place to end. Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
